questions.question_text: Which of the characteristics of civilisation (government/administration, urbanism, crafts, trade, writing, cultural ideas, productive agriculture) do you think is the most fundamental — that is, a characteristic essential to the development of all others?
hints: Consider which characteristic enables others to develop
Think about basic needs and organization
Consider what allows complex societies to form

questions.question_text: You may have come across the term 'Indus Valley civilisation' and noticed that we have not used it. A look at the map (Fig. 6.3 on page 89) explains why the term 'Valley' is obsolete, as we now know that the civilisation extended much beyond the Indus region.
hints: Examine the geographical spread on the map
Consider why names change with new discoveries
Think about accuracy in historical terminology

questions.question_text: Imagine the large number of workers required to build such a network of reservoirs. Who do you think organised their work and gave them precise instructions? How do you think they were paid for their labour? (Hint: there was no money at that time in the way we have today.) Since the reservoirs needed to be cleaned from time to time, was there some local authority to manage their maintenance? What clues do we get from all this about this city's ruler and municipal administration? Use your imagination and discuss with your teacher.
hints: Think about barter systems and community labor
Analyze evidence of urban planning and management

questions.question_text: Looking at the objects on pages 100 and 101 — or any other pictured in this chapter — can you make out what activities or aspects of life were important for the Harappans?
hints: Consider daily life vs. cultural activities
Look for patterns in artifact types

questions.question_text: The Harappans returned to rural settlements because a rural lifestyle gives easier access to food and water than an urban lifestyle. Then as now, cities depended on villages to provide food, and sometimes water.

For each characteristic in the list of civilisation characteristics (government/administration, urbanism, crafts, trade, writing, cultural ideas, productive agriculture), can you make a list of professions or occupations that might exist in such a society?
hints: Consider specialized roles in complex societies

questions.question_text: Some of the important cities of this civilisation are marked in the map (Fig. 6.3). As a class activity, can you try to match these cities with the modern states or regions in the table on the next page? (Cities: Dholavira, Harappa, Kalibangan, Mohenjo-daro, Rakhigarhi; Modern states/regions: Punjab, Gujarat, Sindh, Haryana, Rajasthan)
hints: Use geographical clues from the text

questions.question_text: Have a debate in class about the possible interpretations of Mohenjo-daro's Great Bath: a bath for the royal family only; or a tank used for religious rituals. Can you think of any others? Remember that in this case, we do not have any other source of history — no inscription, no text, no traveller's account.
hints: Consider alternative uses for water structures
Think about social and religious practices

questions.question_text: As a class activity, measure the length of your classroom, a school corridor or a playground with the help of any measuring tape. Compare these lengths with the length of the largest reservoir in Dholavira (73 metres).

Imagine you cook a meal in a Harappan house. What dish or dishes would you prepare, based on the data given above about Harappan diet (barley, wheat, millets, rice, pulses, vegetables, dairy products, turmeric, ginger, banana, meat, fish)?
hints: Consider cooking methods of the time

questions.question_text: Looking at these three Harappan seals with some writing signs (unicorn seal, bull seal, horned tiger seal), what goes through your mind? Would you like to suggest any interpretations? Let your imagination run!

Complete the story found on the Lothal pot which seems to tell the story of the thirsty crow, who finds a clever way to drink water at the bottom of the pot. How was such a story remembered for more than 4,000 years, in your opinion?
hints: Recall or create the crow story

questions.question_text: Consider the 'Dancing Girl' figurine. What do you make of the attitude the figurine expresses? Observe her bangles covering an entire arm, a practice still visible in parts of Gujarat and Rajasthan. Where else in this chapter can you spot bangles worn in this manner? What conclusion should we draw from this?
hints: Look for other bangle examples in images

questions.question_text: Why are the inhabitants of this civilisation called 'Harappans' today? That is simply because the city of Harappa (today in Pakistan's Punjab) was the first of this civilisation to be excavated, way back in 1920–21, over a century ago.
hints: Think about naming conventions in archaeology
Remember first discoveries often set names

questions.question_text: The Harappans mastered the art of working copper, a soft metal. If tin is added to copper, the resulting metal is bronze, which is harder than copper. The Harappans used bronze to make tools, pots and pans, and, as we will see later, some figurines.
Why does the civilisation studied in this chapter have several names? Discuss their significance.
Write a brief report (150 to 200 words) summing up some of the achievements of the Indus-Sarasvatī civilisation.
hints: Cover urban planning, water management, trade, crafts
Include specific examples from the chapter
Structure with introduction, main points, conclusion

questions.question_text: Imagine you have to travel from the city of Harappa to Kalibangan. What are your different options? Can you make a rough estimation of the amount of time each option might take?
hints: Estimate based on distance and mode of travel

questions.question_text: Let us imagine a Harappan man or woman being transported to an average kitchen in today's India. What are the four or five biggest surprises awaiting them?
hints: Compare ancient and modern cooking tools
Think about kitchen appliances and utilities

questions.question_text: Looking at all the pictures in this chapter, make a list of the ornaments / gestures / objects that still feel familiar in our 21st century.
hints: Examine jewelry, clothing, tools in images
Look for continuity in cultural practices

questions.question_text: What mindset does the system of reservoirs at Dholavira reflect?
In Mohenjo-daro, about 700 wells built with bricks have been counted. They seem to have been regularly maintained and used for several centuries. Discuss the implications.
hints: Consider population size and water needs

questions.question_text: It is often said that the Harappans had a high civic sense. Discuss the significance of this statement. Do you agree with it? Compare with citizens in a large city of India today.
hints: Compare ancient and modern civic behavior
